summary: This is a legal filing by attorneys for two victims (Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2) in response to the U.S. Government's notice claiming no need for an evidentiary hearing regarding the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA). The document argues the Government violated the victims' rights by entering into a confidential Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein in September 2007 without conferring with them, and requests the court to order production of the agreement and an FBI interview report. This is a legal filing by attorneys for Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2, arguing the U.S. Government violated their rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) by negotiating a non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein without conferring with them. The filing requests the court to order the government to produce the full non-prosecution agreement and an FBI interview report of Jane Doe #1, and to schedule a hearing on remedies for the rights violations.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The billionaire sex offender who entered into a confidential Non-Prosecution Agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office in September 2007, blocking federal prosecution for sex crimes against minors.

persons.name: Jane Doe #1
persons.context: A victim in the Epstein case who was interviewed by the FBI in October 2007. She is a petitioner in this filing seeking disclosure of the non-prosecution agreement and her FBI interview report.

persons.name: Jane Doe #2
persons.context: A victim in the Epstein case and co-petitioner with Jane Doe #1, arguing her rights under the CVRA were violated by the government's non-prosecution agreement with Epstein.

persons.name: A. Marie Villafaña
persons.context: The federal prosecutor handling the Epstein case. She sent victim notification letters, secured pro bono counsel for victims, and communicated with victims' attorney Bradley Edwards about the case.

persons.name: Bradley Edwards
persons.context: The attorney representing Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2. He corresponded with AUSA Villafaña, filed emergency motions to protect victims' rights, and requested the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: E. Nesbitt Kuyrkendall
persons.context: FBI agent who, along with Jason Richards, met with Jane Doe #1 on October 26, 2007, to discuss the Epstein case but did not disclose the existence of the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: Jason Richards
persons.context: FBI agent who, along with E. Nesbitt Kuyrkendall, met with Jane Doe #1 on October 26, 2007, to discuss the Epstein case but did not disclose the existence of the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: Meg Garvin
persons.role: Attorney, National Crime Victims' Law Institute
persons.context: Attorney contacted by AUSA Villafaña to secure pro bono counsel for Jane Doe #1. She was not advised about the Non-Prosecution Agreement during the call.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Attorney representing Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2, who signed and filed this legal document.

persons.name: Paul G. Cassell
persons.context: Attorney representing Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2, listed as counsel on the filing.

persons.name: Dexter A. Lee
persons.context: The Assistant U.S. Attorney listed on the service list, representing the government in this matter.

connections.description: Villafaña, as the Assistant U.S. Attorney, negotiated and entered into a confidential Non-Prosecution Agreement with Epstein on behalf of the U.S. Government.
Edwards, as attorney for the victims, communicated with prosecutor Villafaña regarding the case, requested information, and discussed the possibility of federal charges.
Epstein is accused of committing federal sex crimes against Jane Doe #1 while she was a minor.
Epstein is accused of committing federal sex crimes against Jane Doe #2 while she was a minor.
Both were FBI Special Agents who jointly conducted an interview with Jane Doe #1 on October 26, 2007.
Edwards is the legal representative for victim Jane Doe #1 in proceedings related to the CVRA and Epstein case.
Edwards is the legal representative for victim Jane Doe #2 in proceedings related to the CVRA and Epstein case.
Edwards is listed as the attorney representing Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2 in this legal filing.
Edwards is listed as the attorney representing Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2 in this legal filing.
Cassell is listed as co-counsel for the petitioners, Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2.
Lee, as an Assistant U.S. Attorney, is part of the government that negotiated the non-prosecution agreement with Epstein.

events.title: FBI Investigation Opened
events.description: At the request of the Palm Beach Police Department, the FBI opened an investigation into allegations that Jeffrey Epstein used interstate commerce to induce minors into prostitution.

events.title: Victim Notification Letter Sent
events.description: Assistant U.S. Attorney A. Marie Villafaña sent a letter to Jane Doe #1 informing her of her rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA).

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Finalized
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida entered into a confidential Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, blocking federal prosecution in favor of state prosecution under certain conditions.

events.title: FBI Meeting with Jane Doe #1
events.description: FBI Special Agents E. Nesbitt Kuyrkendall and Jason Richards met with Jane Doe #1 at a restaurant. They discussed possible resolutions but did not disclose the finalized Non-Prosecution Agreement due to its confidentiality clause.

events.title: Misleading FBI Letters Sent
events.description: Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2 received letters from the FBI stating the case was 'currently under investigation,' despite the Non-Prosecution Agreement having been concluded four months prior.

events.title: Attorney's Letter Urging Prosecution
events.description: Bradley Edwards sent a letter to AUSA Villafaña urging the filing of federal criminal charges against Epstein, unaware that a Non-Prosecution Agreement already existed.

events.title: First Disclosure of Agreement to Victims
events.description: AUSA Villafaña sent a victim notification to Jane Doe #1 via Bradley Edwards, providing a written explanation of some terms of the Non-Prosecution Agreement. This was the first time the victims learned it blocked federal charges.

events.title: Court Hearing on Emergency Motion
events.description: The court held a hearing on the victims' emergency motion to protect their CVRA rights. The Government discussed provisions of the Non-Prosecution Agreement in open court.

events.title: Epstein Files Motion for Stay
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein filed a motion to stay a civil action, claiming it was a counterpart to a pending federal criminal action, based on the non-prosecution agreement.

events.title: FBI Interview of Jane Doe #1
events.description: Two named FBI agents met with Jane Doe #1 for an interview. The government has a report of this interview but has declined to produce it to her.

events.title: Filing of Victims' Rights Motion
events.description: Attorneys for Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2 file this document, asking the court to find CVRA violations and order production of the non-prosecution agreement and interview report.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office entered into a confidential Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein in September 2007, which contained an 'express confidentiality provision' preventing disclosure to victims.

The agreement blocked federal prosecution of Epstein for sex crimes against minors, contingent on a state conviction requiring sex offender registration, and envisioned victims pursuing civil rights actions.
FBI agents met with victim Jane Doe #1 in October 2007 but did not disclose the existence of the finalized agreement, leading her to believe the federal investigation was ongoing.
The Government sent letters to victims in January 2008 stating the case was 'currently under investigation,' despite the agreement being signed months earlier.
The victims' attorneys first learned of the Non-Prosecution Agreement on or after July 9, 2008, nearly ten months after it was finalized, when the Government filed a responsive pleading.

The filing argues the U.S. Government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) by negotiating a non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein without conferring with the victims, Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2.
The victims' attorneys request the court to order the government to produce the full, secret non-prosecution agreement and any addenda, which is central to the litigation.
The filing reveals the government has an FBI report of an interview with Jane Doe #1 from October 26, 2007, but has declined to provide it to her, which the motion seeks to compel.

The victims seek a judicial declaration that their rights were violated, an apology from the government, and a hearing to determine the appropriate remedy, but are not seeking to invalidate the non-prosecution agreement.
The document is a formal court filing (Document 19) in Case No. 9:08-cv-80736-KAM, entered on the docket on August 1, 2008.
